Title: Pharmacological Interactions between Ibuprofen and Metformin: Mechanisms and Clinical Implications

Authors: X. Zhang, Y. Liu, J. Wang

Journal: Pharmacology Research

Abstract:
This study investigates the interactions between ibuprofen and metformin, focusing on their pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic interactions. Ibuprofen inhibits the renal clearance of metformin, leading to an increase in metformin plasma concentration. This interaction is mediated by organic anion transport proteins (OATPs) and glutathione S-transferases (GSTs). The clinical implications of this interaction include an increased risk of lactic acidosis and gastrointestinal side effects.

Text:

Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is commonly used for the treatment of pain and inflammation. Metformin, an antidiabetic medication, is primarily used for the management of type 2 diabetes.

FREQUENCY: Ibuprofen, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, treatment, pain, inflammation

The concomitant use of ibuprofen and metformin has been reported to result in pharmacological interactions. Pharmacodynamic interactions between these two drugs have been extensively studied, but pharmacokinetic interactions have received less attention.

FREQUENCY: ibuprofen and metformin, pharmacological interactions, pharmacodynamic interactions, pharmacokinetic interactions

Pharmacokinetic interactions between ibuprofen and metformin have been observed primarily in the renal clearance of metformin. Ibuprofen inhibits the renal clearance of metformin, leading to an increase in metformin plasma concentration.

FREQUENCY: ibuprofen, metformin, renal clearance, plasma concentration

"ABSTRACT":

"Pharmacological interventions are essential in the management of hypertension, a major risk factor for cardiovascular diseases. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs), angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), and diuretics are commonly used classes of antihypertensive drugs. CCBs, which include nifedipine, amlodipine, and verapamil, act by inhibiting the influx of calcium ions into the myoplasmic sarcoplasmic reticulum of cardiac and smooth muscle cells. ACE inhibitors, such as enalapril and lisinopril, inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, thereby reducing the vasoconstriction and increasing the production of bradykinin, a vasodilator. ARBs, including losartan and valsartan, block the angiotensin II receptor, leading to vasodilation and decreased production of aldosterone. Diuretics, such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide, increase the excretion of sodium and water, thereby reducing the total body fluid volume and blood pressure. These classes of drugs have different mechanisms of action and side effects, and their choice depends on the individual patient's response and tolerance."

Title: Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of Fentanyl: An Overview

Authors: X. Y. Zhang, M. Doe, J. Smith

Journal: Pharmacology Research & Perspectives

Year: 2021

Abstract:
This review aims to provide an overview of the pharmacokinetics (PK) and pharmacodynamics (PD) of fentanyl, a widely used opioid analgesic. Fentanyl is a potent agonist of μ-opioid receptors (MORs), and its PK and PD properties are crucial for understanding its therapeutic and adverse effects.

Text:

Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid agonist, primarily acting on μ-opioid receptors (MORs). It is approximately 100 times more potent than morphine and 50 times more potent than sufentanil.

Pharmacokinetics:

Absorption: Fentanyl is available in various formulations, including transdermal patches, buccal tablets, sublingual tablets, and intravenous (IV) injections. Transdermal patches are the most commonly used route for chronic pain management. After application, fentanyl is absorbed through the skin and into the systemic circulation.

Distribution: Fentanyl has a high protein binding capacity, with approximately 85% binding to plasma proteins, mainly α1-acid glycoprotein and albumin. Its volume of distribution is approximately 3-4 L/kg.

Metabolism: Fentanyl undergoes N-dealkylation by CYP3A4 to form norfentanyl, which is then conjugated with glucuronide to form norfentanyl glucuronide (NFG). NFG is the major metabolite of fentanyl and is pharmacologically active.

Excretion: Fentanyl and its metabolites are primarily excreted in the urine. The elimination half-life of fentanyl is approximately 18 hours, while that of norfentanyl is around 24 hours.

Pharmacology of Ibuprofen: Mechanisms of Action and Clinical Applications

Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is one of the most commonly used medications for the treatment of pain and inflammation. It exerts its effects primarily by inhibiting cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, specifically COX-1 and COX-2.

COX-1: This isoform is constitutively expressed in various tissues, including the gastrointestinal tract, and plays a role in the production of prostaglandins involved in the protection of the gastric mucosa.

COX-2: This isoform is inducible and is primarily expressed in inflammatory tissues. It is responsible for the production of prostaglandins involved in inflammation and pain. Ibuprofen inhibits COX-2 more effectively than COX-1, which contributes to its analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects.

Prostaglandins: These are lipid autacoids that play crucial roles in various physiological processes, including inflammation, pain perception, and platelet aggregation.

NSAIDs: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen, are a class of drugs used for the treatment of pain and inflammation. They work by inhibiting the COX enzymes.

Cyclooxygenase (COX): A group of enzymes responsible for the biosynthesis of prostaglandins from arachidonic acid. COX exists as two isoforms: COX-1 and COX-2.

Arachidonic acid: A polyunsaturated fatty acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and thromboxanes.

Lipid autacoids: Biologically active lipid molecules that act as signaling agents in various cellular processes.

Physiological processes: Natural functions or activities that occur in living organisms.

Platelet aggregation: The process by which platelets adhere to each other and form a platelet clot to prevent blood

Meanwhile, the exclusion criteria were: 1) women who became menopausal from surgery or chemotherapy; 2) women who underwent hysterectomy; 3) women with a history of endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial, breast, or sex hormone–related cancers; 4) women with uncontrolled hypertension (160/100 mmHg or higher); 5) women with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (fasting blood sugar 180 mg/dL or higher, or cases of starting or changing medication due to diabetes within 3 mo); 6) uncontrolled thyroid patients; 7) women who have had severe migraines within the last year or who have been diagnosed with thromboembolism, cerebrovascular disease, or serious cardiovascular disease; 8) women with atypical uterine bleeding after 1 yr of menopause; 9) women who have taken sleep inducers, antidepressants, selective estrogen receptor modulators, antihyperlipidemic drugs, antithrombotic drugs (Aspirin, Warfarin, and Clopidogrel), bisphosphonates, or calcitonin within 4 wk; 10) women who have taken plant hormones (isoflavone, flaxseed, pomegranate, horseradish, white sorghum, red shamrock, and red ginseng products) in the form of supplements or medicines within 4 wk; 11) women who have continuously taken functional foods and herbal medicines that could affect bone health, blood lipid lipids (triglyceride and cholesterol), and blood circulation within 4 wk; 12) women who were administered female hormone formulations within 6 mo; 13) women with alanine aminotransferase (ALT) or aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels exceeding 3 times the laboratory's normal upper limit; 14) women with creatinine levels exceeding 2 times the laboratory's normal upper limit; 15) women with a history of drug or alcohol abuse; 16) women who have performed intensive exercises (more than 10 h) within 3 mo; 17) women with hypersensitivity to the test drug or its ingredients; 18) women with clinically significant abnormalities based on mammographies or Pap smears (Category 0 or higher than 3 of Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS)) is confirmed (in the case of BI-RADS Category 0, subject registration is possible after confirming additional test results; in the case of Pap smear, atypical squamous cell of undetermined significance can be registered); 19) women who have participated in other clinical trials within 1 mo of the start of the current study or who are planning to participate in another clinical trial during the study period; and, 20) in cases where the researchers decided that the subject is unsuitable to participate in this study.

Pharmacology of Ibuprofen: Mechanisms of Action and Clinical Applications

Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is one of the most commonly used medications worldwide for the treatment of pain and inflammation.

Mechanisms of Action:
1. Cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibition: Ibuprofen inhibits the enzyme COX, which is responsible for the production of prostaglandins, thereby reducing inflammation and pain.
2. Inhibition of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS): Ibuprofen inhibits iNOS, which leads to a decrease in nitric oxide production and, consequently, reduces inflammation.
3. Antagonism of leukotriene B4 (LTB4): Ibuprofen acts as an antagonist of LTB4, which is a potent inflammatory mediator.

Clinical Applications:
1. Pain relief: Ibuprofen is used for the relief of various types of pain, including headache, menstrual cramps, and musculoskeletal pain.
2. Anti-inflammatory effects: Ibuprofen is used to reduce inflammation in conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis.
3. Antipyretic effects: Ibuprofen is used to reduce fever.
4. Gastrointestinal (GI) protection: Ibuprofen has been shown to have GI protective effects, making it a preferred choice over other NSAIDs for patients at risk of GI complications.

References:
[1] Dahl CO, Lund-Moller S. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs: mechanisms of action and clinical applications. Anesthesiology. 1991;75(6):921-933.
[2] Smith JA, Willis WD. Ibuprofen: a review of its pharmacology and therapeutic uses. Clin Pharmacokinet. 1992;23(11):6

Pharmacology of Ibuprofen: Mechanisms of Action and Clinical Applications

Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is one of the most commonly used medications for the treatment of pain and inflammation. Its therapeutic effects are primarily attributed to its inhibitory action on cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes.

1. Cyclooxygenase (COX):
The COX enzymes are responsible for the biosynthesis of prostaglandins, which are mediators of inflammation and pain. Ibuprofen inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2 isoforms, leading to a reduction in prostaglandin production and subsequent relief of pain and inflammation.

2. Prostaglandins:
Prostaglandins are lipid mediators that play crucial roles in various physiological processes, including inflammation, pain perception, and platelet aggregation. They are synthesized from arachidonic acid through the action of COX enzymes.

3. COX-1 and COX-2:
COX-1 is constitutively expressed in various tissues, including the gastrointestinal tract, and is responsible for the production of prostaglandins involved in maintaining homeostasis. COX-2, on the other hand, is an inducible isoform, which is upregulated in response to inflammatory stimuli and is primarily responsible for the production of prostaglandins involved in inflammation and pain.

4. Mechanisms of Action:
The primary mechanism of action of ibuprofen is its inhibitory effect on COX enzymes, leading to a decrease in prostaglandin production. Additionally, ibuprofen has been shown to exhibit other pharmacological actions, including inhibition of leukotriene synthesis, inhibition of platelet aggregation, and modulation of cytokine production.

5. Clinical Applications:
Ibuprofen is widely used for the treatment of various conditions, including pain, inflammation, and fever. It is commonly used in the management of musculoskeletal disorders, such as osteoarthritis

The mechanisms of herb–drug interactions are complex and multifactorial. They can occur at various levels, including:
absorption: ["absorption"],
distribution: ["distribution"],
metabolism: ["metabolism"],
excretion: ["excretion"],
pharmacodynamics: ["pharmacodynamics"],
and toxicology: ["toxicology"].

For instance, St. John's wort (Hypericum perforatum) is a well-known herb that interacts with various drugs through different mechanisms. It can:
inhibit the metabolism of:
"cyclosporine": [1],
"theophylline": [1],
"warfarin": [1],
"digoxin": [1],
and
"imipenem": [1],
among others. It can also:
enhance the effect of:
"tricyclic antidepressants": [1],
"monoamine oxidase inhibitors": [1],
and
"benzodiazepines": [1].

Another example is ginseng (Panax ginseng), which can:
affect the absorption of:
"digoxin": [1],
"warfarin": [1],
and
"aspirin": [1],
and
alter the metabolism of:
"cyclosporine": [1],
"theophylline": [1],
and
"phenytoin": [1].

In conclusion, herb–drug interactions are a significant concern in clinical practice due to their potential to alter the therapeutic effect, toxicity, or both of herbs and drugs. A thorough understanding of the mechanisms and specific interactions is essential for safe and effective combined use.

1. Introduction

"Opioid use disorder" (OUD): Opioid use disorder is a chronic relapsing brain disorder characterized by the persistent use of opioids despite the harmful consequences.

"Opioids" (Morphine, Heroin, Fentanyl, Oxycodone, Hydromorphone, etc.): Opioids are a class of drugs that include the natural substance morphine, which is found in the opium poppy, and synthetic drugs such as fentanyl and oxycodone.

"Morphine" (Morphine sulfate, Morphine base): Morphine is a naturally occurring opioid alkaloid derived from the opium poppy.

"Heroin" (Diacetylmorphine): Heroin is a highly addictive opioid drug that is synthesized from morphine.

"Fentanyl": Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid that is 50 to 100 times more potent than morphine.

"Oxycodone" (Oxycodone hydrochloride): Oxycodone is a semi-synthetic opioid that is derived from thebaine, an opioid alkaloid found in the opium poppy.

"Hydromorphone" (Hydromorphone hydrochloride): Hydromorphone is a semi-synthetic opioid that is derived from morphine.

"Opioid receptors" (μ-opioid receptors, δ-opioid receptors, κ-opioid receptors): Opioid receptors are a class of G protein-coupled receptors that mediate the effects of opioids.

"μ-opioid receptors" (MORs): μ-opioid receptors are the primary target for the therapeutic effects of opioids.

Title: Pharmacological Interactions between Ibuprofen and Metformin: A Case Report

Authors: A.B. Clinician1, C.D. Pharmacist2

Affiliations:
1. Department of Internal Medicine, University Hospital, City, Country
2. Department of Pharmacy, University Hospital, City, Country

Abstract:
We report a case of a 55-year-old female patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus who experienced an adverse drug reaction after initiating concomitant therapy with ibuprofen and metformin.

Text:
Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is commonly used for the treatment of pain and inflammation. Metformin, an antidiabetic medication, is primarily used for the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Case Report:
A 55-year-old female patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus was prescribed ibuprofen 400 mg three times daily for pain management and metformin 1000 mg twice daily for glycemic control. After one week of concomitant therapy, the patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of lactic acidosis.

Laboratory findings revealed a serum lactate level of 4.5 mmol/L (normal range: 0.5-2.2 mmol/L), a serum bicarbonate level of 15 mEq/L (normal range: 22-26 mEq/L), and a serum creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL (normal range: 0.6-1.3 mg/dL). The patient was treated with intravenous fluids and bicarbonate, and her symptoms improved.

The possible pharmacological interaction between ibuprofen and metformin has been reported in previous studies. Ibuprofen inhibits the renal tubular secretion of metformin, leading to an increase in metformin plasma concentration and an increased risk of lactic acidosis.

Title: "Pharmacological Interactions between Ibuprofen and Metformin: A Case Report"

Authors: A.B. Author1, C.D. Author2

Journal: Journal of Clinical Pharmacy and Therapeutics

Abstract:

"Background: Ibuprofen and metformin are commonly used medications. The potential pharmacological interactions between these two drugs are not well understood.

Case Report: We report a case of a 55-year-old female patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus who experienced an adverse event after taking ibuprofen and metformin concomitantly. The patient presented with symptoms of gastrointestinal distress, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Laboratory tests revealed an elevated creatinine level, suggesting renal impairment. The patient's ibuprofen and metformin doses were reduced, and her symptoms resolved.

Discussion: The mechanisms underlying the interaction between ibuprofen and metformin are not fully understood. However, it is believed that ibuprofen may inhibit the renal tubular secretion of metformin, leading to increased metformin levels and potential renal toxicity.

Conclusion: This case report highlights the importance of being aware of potential pharmacological interactions between commonly used medications, such as ibuprofen and metformin. Healthcare professionals should consider monitoring renal function in patients taking these medications concomitantly."

Title: Pharmacological Interactions between Ibuprofen and Metformin: A Case Report

Authors: A. Doctor1, B. Pharmacist2, C. Researcher3

Affiliations:
1. Department of Pharmacy, XYZ Hospital
2. Department of Pharmacy, XYZ Hospital
3. Department of Pharmacology, ABC University

Abstract:
This case report describes the pharmacological interaction between ibuprofen and metformin in a 58-year-old female patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic pain.

Text:

Background: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used for pain relief and antipyretic effects. Metformin is an oral antidiabetic medication, primarily used for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Case Report: A 58-year-old female patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. She was prescribed ibuprofen 400 mg every 6 hours for pain relief. Concurrently, she was taking metformin 1000 mg twice daily for glycemic control.

Pharmacokinetics: Ibuprofen: The half-life of ibuprofen is approximately 2 hours. Metformin: The half-life of metformin is around 6 hours.

Interaction: The patient experienced an unexpected decrease in her blood glucose levels after taking ibuprofen and metformin together. This interaction is believed to be due to the inhibition of CYP2C8 and CYP2C9 by ibuprofen, which results in increased metformin bioavailability and subsequent increased risk of hypoglycemia.

Discussion: The interaction between ibuprofen and metformin highlights the importance of monitoring patients taking both medications for potential adverse effects. This case report emphasizes the need for healthcare professionals to be aware of the potential pharmacological interactions between NSAIDs and oral antidiabetic medications.

Case Report: Fatigue and Bleeding in a Polymedicated Patient Using Several Herbal Supplementations, Detected with g-Nomic® Software Abel Saldarreaga Marin, 1 Marc Cendros, 2 Carlos J Ciudad, 3 and Ana Sabater 2 Author information Article notes Copyright and License information PMC Disclaimer Go to: Abstract  This was a case report of severe fatigue and bleeding in a 65-year-old man with ischemic heart disease who was wearing a stent and taking multiple medications for hypertension and diabetes.

"Patient": [1], "[65-year-old man]"
"Diseases": ["ischemic heart disease"]

Abstract: This was a case report of severe fatigue and bleeding in a 65-year-old man with ischemic heart disease who was wearing a stent and taking multiple medications for hypertension and diabetes.

The patient reported a sudden onset of severe fatigue and was found to have a hemorrhagic event. A comprehensive medication review was performed using g-Nomic® Software, which identified several herbal supplementations that the patient was taking. The herbal supplements included garlic, ginkgo biloba, and omega-3 fatty acids.

The patient was advised to discontinue the use of these supplements and was closely monitored. His symptoms improved, and he was eventually discharged from the hospital. The authors concluded that the use of multiple herbal supplementations can lead to adverse drug interactions and potentially life-threatening complications.

Drug interactions can be considered illnesses by themselves.

"DRUG INTERACTIONS": []

The complex interplay between multiple drugs can lead to unintended pharmacological effects, potentially resulting in adverse outcomes. These interactions can be categorized based on the mechanisms involved, including: pharmacodynamic, pharmacokinetic, and metabolic interactions.

"PHARMACODYNAMIC INTERACTIONS": [1, 2]

Pharmacodynamic interactions occur when the combined effects of two or more drugs on a biological system result in altered responses. These interactions can lead to enhanced, decreased, or even opposite effects compared to the individual drugs. For instance, the co-administration of warfarin and aspirin can result in increased anticoagulant effects due to the synergistic inhibition of platelet aggregation and thromboxane synthesis.

"PHARMACOKINETIC INTERACTIONS": [1, 3, 4]

Pharmacokinetic interactions involve alterations in the absorption, distribution, metabolism, or excretion of one or both drugs. For example, the co-administration of cyclosporine and tacrolimus can result in increased cyclosporine levels due to the inhibition of its metabolism by tacrolimus.

"METABOLIC INTERACTIONS": [1, 3, 5]

Metabolic interactions occur when one drug affects the metabolism of another drug, leading to altered pharmacokinetics. For instance, the co-administration of fluconazole and theophylline can result in increased theophylline levels due to the inhibition of its metabolism by fluconazole.

Radix Isatidis (Root of Isatis indigotica Fort., Banlangen).

"FREQUENCY": ["Radix Isatidis", "Root", "Isatis indigotica", "Fort.", "Banlangen"]

The root of Isatis indigotica Fort. (Radix Isatidis, Banlangen) is a commonly used traditional Chinese medicine. It has been shown to exhibit various pharmacological activities, including:

Anti-inflammatory effects:
The extract of Radix Isatidis inhibits the production of nitric oxide (NO) and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-stimulated RAW 264.7 macrophages. It also suppresses the expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) in these cells.

Antioxidant properties:
Radix Isatidis extract exhibits strong antioxidant activity, as evidenced by its ability to scavenge superoxide anion radicals, hydroxyl radicals, and 1,1-diphenyl-2-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) radicals. It also increases the activity of superoxide dismutase (SOD) and glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) in the liver of mice.

Antiviral activity:
Radix Isatidis extract inhibits the replication of influenza A virus in MDCK cells, as shown by a decrease in viral titers and a reduction in the expression of viral proteins. It also enhances the production of interferon-β (IFN-β) and interferon-γ (IFN-γ) in these cells.

Immunomodulatory effects:
Radix Isatidis extract stimulates the proliferation of splenocytes and enhances the production of interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon-γ (IFN-γ), and interleukin-12 (IL-12) in vitro. It also increases the number of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells and the production of immunoglobulin G (IgG) in mice.

"ABSTRACT": ["This study aimed to characterize the pharmacological properties of a novel small-molecule agonist (compound 1) for a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR). Compound 1 was found to bind selectively to the target GPCR and elicited a robust agonist response in functional assays. The binding affinity of compound 1 was determined using radioligand binding assays. The pharmacological profile of compound 1 was further investigated using whole-cell patch-clamp recordings and calcium flux measurements. The results demonstrated that compound 1 was a full agonist with high potency and efficacy. These findings provide valuable insights into the pharmacology of this novel GPCR and lay the foundation for the development of selective modulators for therapeutic applications."

Title: Pharmacological Interactions between Ibuprofen and Metformin: A Case Report

Authors: A. Doctor1, B. Pharmacist2, C. Researcher3

Affiliations:
1. Department of Pharmacy, XYZ Hospital
2. Department of Pharmacy, XYZ Hospital
3. Department of Pharmacology, ABC University

Abstract:
This case report describes the pharmacological interaction between ibuprofen and metformin in a 58-year-old female patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic pain.

Text:
The patient was prescribed ibuprofen 400 mg three times daily for pain management and metformin 500 mg twice daily for glycemic control. After a week of concomitant use, the patient presented with symptoms of lactic acidosis, including fatigue, muscle cramps, and shortness of breath.

Laboratory tests confirmed elevated lactate levels (3.5 mmol/L) and metformin plasma concentration (2.5 µg/mL). The patient was advised to discontinue ibuprofen and was closely monitored. Her symptoms improved, and lactate levels returned to normal within 48 hours.

Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used for pain relief and antipyretic effects. Metformin is an antidiabetic medication, primarily used for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Ibuprofen: 3 times daily
Metformin: 2 times daily

Title: Pharmacological Interactions between Ibuprofen and Metformin: Mechanisms and Clinical Implications

Authors: X. Zhang, Y. Liu, J. Wang

Journal: Pharmacology Research

Year: 2021

Abstract:
This study investigates the interactions between ibuprofen and metformin, focusing on their pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic interactions. Ibuprofen inhibits the renal clearance of metformin, leading to increased metformin plasma concentration. This interaction is mediated by organic anion transport proteins (OATPs) and glutathione S-transferases (GSTs). The clinical implications of this interaction include an increased risk of lactic acidosis and gastrointestinal side effects.

Text:

Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is commonly used for the treatment of pain and inflammation. Metformin, an antidiabetic medication, is primarily used for the management of type 2 diabetes.

FREQUENCY: Ibuprofen, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, treatment, pain, inflammation

The concomitant use of ibuprofen and metformin has been reported to result in pharmacological interactions. Pharmacodynamic interactions between these two drugs have been extensively studied, but pharmacokinetic interactions have received less attention.

FREQUENCY: ibuprofen and metformin, pharmacological interactions, pharmacodynamic interactions, pharmacokinetic interactions

Pharmacokinetic interactions between ibuprofen and metformin primarily involve the renal clearance of metformin. Ibuprofen inhibits the renal clearance of metformin, leading to increased metformin plasma concentration.

FREQUENCY: ibuprofen, metformin, renal clearance, plasma concentration

Title: "Pharmacological Interventions in the Management of Opioid Use Disorder: Current Perspectives"

Authors: [A. Kumar, S. S. S. Prasad]

Abstract: [The abstract is not considered for entity extraction as it is often introductory and not specific enough to extract entities related to pharmacology.]

Text:

1. Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a chronic relapsing brain disorder characterized by the following:
   - Compulsive drug-seeking behavior
   - Loss of control over drug intake
   - Craving for the drug
   - Negative physiological and psychological effects

2. Opioid receptors (μ-opioid receptor, δ-opioid receptor, κ-opioid receptor) are the primary targets for pharmacological interventions in OUD.

3. Opioid agonists (buprenorphine, methadone, fentanyl, oxycodone, hydrocodone) are used for the treatment of OUD.

4. Opioid agonists bind to opioid receptors and produce analgesic effects, reduce cravings, and block the effects of illicit opioids.

5. Opioid antagonists (naloxone, naltrexone) are used for the treatment of opioid overdose and as a maintenance therapy for OUD.

6. Opioid antagonists block the effects of opioid agonists by binding to opioid receptors and preventing agonist binding.

7. Opioid partial agonists (buprenorphine) have a lower potential for abuse and dependence compared to full opioid agonists.

8. Opioid receptor modulators (G protein-biased ligands) have the potential to produce therapeutic effects without the addictive properties of opioid agonists.

9. Combination therapies (methadone and buprenorphine, buprenorphine and naloxone) are used for the treatment of OUD and have shown to be effective in reducing opioid cravings and improving patient outcomes.
